problem_text:
This question is about existence of an analogue of the Lazard correspondence for pre-Lie algebras and braces. A pre-Lie algebra A is a vector space with a bilinear operation (x, y) → xy satisfying (xy)z − x(yz) = (yx)z − y(xz) for every x, y, z ∈ A. A pre-Lie algebra A is said to be left nilpotent if, for some n ∈ N, A·(A·(A · · · A))) = 0 where A appears n times in the product. Recall that a set A with binary operations + and ◦ is a left brace if (A, +) is an abelian group, (A, ◦) is a group, and a ◦ (b + c) + a = a ◦ b + a ◦ c for every a, b, c ∈ A. Let p be a prime, and F_p the field of p elements. A left brace A is called an F_p-brace if its additive group is an F_p-vector space such that a ∗ (αb) = α(a ∗ b) for all a, b ∈ A, α ∈ F_p, where a ∗ b = a ◦ b − a − b. The idea of a connection between braces and pre-Lie algebras comes from a paper by W. Rump (2014).

a) Let A be an F_p-brace of cardinality p^k for some k. Is it true that when p is sufficiently large relative to k, the set A with the same additive operation + and with the operation · defined as a · b = −\sum_{i=0}^{p−2} \frac{1}{2^i} ((2^i a) ∗ b) is a pre-Lie algebra?
Comment of 2025: If 2 ≡ ξ^{p^{n−1}} when ξ is a primitive root modulo p, and if A is strongly nilpotent of nilpotency index less than p, then the result follows by (A. Smoktunowicz, Adv. Math., 409, part B (2022), 108683). It is not known if the result follows when A is not strongly nilpotent.

b) Let k be a natural number, and let p be a prime number such that p > 2k. Is there a bijective correspondence between F_p-braces of cardinality p^k and left nilpotent pre-Lie algebras over F_p of cardinality p^k?

An affirmative answer to any of the above questions would have consequences for the theory of set-theoretic solutions of the Yang–Baxter equation and for the theory of Hopf–Galois extensions.
A. Smoktunowicz
answer: b) Yes, there is (S. Trappeniers, Preprint, 2024, https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.02475).
